channel.title: briefUpdatesBreakingOffshootNL
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from briefUpdatesBreakingOffshootNL, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Austria’s Hills Are Still Alive, 60 Years Later
item.description: In Salzburg, an anniversary of “The Sound of Music” looks grand through a child’s eyes, even if the locals are gazing elsewhere.

item.title: CDC director is out after less than a month; other agency leaders resign
item.description: "Susan Monarez is no longer director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention," the Department of Health and Human Services wrote in a social...

item.title: Minneapolis Shooting Suspect Knew Her Target, but Motive Is a Mystery
item.description: The shooter who attacked a Catholic school on Wednesday posted social media videos and writings that betrayed a litany of grievances and obsessions.

item.title: A Traumatized Minneapolis Confronts Another Tragedy
item.description: The shooting of children at a Roman Catholic church came after a string of violent confrontations, going back to George Floyd, that has left the Twin ...

item.title: A Casualty of Trump’s Tariffs: India’s Nascent Solar Industry
item.description: The full weight of a 50 percent tariff on Indian goods took effect this week, undercutting one of the country’s most promising markets for solar expor...

item.title: CDC Director Susan Monarez Is Fired, White House Says
item.description: Susan Monarez was said to have refused to adopt Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s stance on vaccination policy.

item.title: Austria’s Hills Are Still Alive, 60 Years Later
item.description: In Salzburg, an anniversary of “The Sound of Music” looks grand through a child’s eyes, even if the locals are gazing elsewhere.

item.title: Jimmy Lai’s Freedom May Now Hinge on Beijing and Trump
item.description: As the outspoken Hong Kong publisher awaits a verdict, his trial has become a test of China’s resolve to crush dissent, and of whether President Trump...

item.title: After Blocking U.N. Nuclear Watchdog, Iran Allows Inspectors to Return
item.description: Iran halted cooperation with the agency last month, as experts warned that Tehran might revive efforts to build a nuclear bomb.

item.title: What to Know About Jimmy Lai’s Trial in Hong Kong
item.description: The media tycoon, jailed since 2020, ran a now-defunct newspaper that was critical of the government.

item.title: Germany Proposes Plan to Boost Recruitment or Resort to Draft
item.description: Some detractors think the new bill is too weak to fill the recruitment gap. Others worry it will inevitably lead to forced conscription.

item.title: Colleges see significant drop in international students as fall semester begins
item.description: Delays and increased screenings for visas mean that many students didn't make it to campus on time – and that has some big implications for the econom...

item.title: Brands are loving Taylor Swift's engagement. Do they need to calm down?
item.description: Companies from Pillsbury to Invisalign to Olipop are cheering — and trying to cash in on — the couple's engagement. Experts spoke to NPR about how bra...

item.title: The latest COVID vaccines come with new FDA limits
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration approved the next round of COVID-19 vaccines, but is restricting them to people at high risk for COVID complications.

item.title: Greetings from the Negev desert, where traces remain of a vanished ancient civilization
item.description: Far-Flung Postcards is a weekly series in which NPR's international team shares moments from their lives and work around the world.
